results.title: The Sacrifice = Offret
results.creator_credit: Anna-Lena Wibom, Svenska filminstitutet, Sveriges Television Sveriges Television TV2, Argos Films, Channel Four and Andrei Tarkovsky
results.brief_description: Alexander, a retired actor, is in the midst of celebrating his birthday with his family when a radio announcement interrupts the party to warn of an imminent nuclear catastrophe. He makes a promise to God that he will sacrifice all he holds dear if the disaster can be averted. The next day dawns and everything seems to be restored to normality. Alexander must now keep his promise - or was it all a dream? Tarkovsky’s cinema has long dealt with the interpenetration of the seen and unseen worlds, visible manifestations of the spiritual battles that are continually being waged around us. By deliberately leaving his visionary images open-ended he hoped their meanings would continue to grow in the mind of the viewer. Tarkovsky died of cancer shortly after completing this film. (Awards: Grand Prix winner, Cannes Film Festival, 1986) In Swedish with English subtitles. Cast includes Erland Josephson, Susan Fleetwood, Valerie Mairesse and Allan Edwell.

results.title: The Sacred cow of India
results.creator_credit: Jim Dale, Mediacast and W.R. Geddes
results.brief_description: A striking feature of India is the prevalence of cows in all the cities and the tolerance and respect with which they are treated. This film traces the origin of the sacred cow concept showing how it is supported, not only by religion but by the practical value of cattle and their products. The story leads the viewer through scenes of bull wrestling in the South, the colourful rural Vishnoi people of Rajasthan, the giant cattle fair of Brahmin priests and the the Hari Krishna cult, and the elevation of cows to divine status.

results.title: The Rutles
results.creator_credit: Rutles, Craig Kellem, Gary Weis and Eric Idle
results.brief_description: The Rutles is a mockumentary, a parody of The Beatles and Beatlemania written and co-directed by Eric Idle, of Monty Python fame. The Rutles are Dirk, Barry, Stig and Nasty. Made for television, “The Rutles” charts the rise of the band of the same name as they progress from English obscurity to world phenomena. Using mockumentary footage and interviews, “The Rutles” documents the pre-fab four’s journey right through to their messy break up and post-Rutle lives. Idle plays a series of characters including Rutle Dirk and a hapless BBC type interviewer who narrates the film. “The Rutles” mocks the BBC, documentary filmmakers, and The Beatles’ films and music. Features excerpts from The Rutles films - Yellow Submarine Sandwich, Tragical History Tour, OUCH!, and A Hard Day’s Rut. Songs include Please rut me, All you need is cash and Twist and rut. “The Rutles” also features George Harrison, John Belushi, Dan Ackroyd, Bianca Jagger, Ron Wood, Mick Jagger, Paul Simon and Bill Murray. “The Rutles” is a sharp and witty send up of any number of documentaries made about The Beatles.

results.title: The Rutherford atom
results.creator_credit: Kevin Smith, Quentin Brown, Physical Sciences Study Committee and Educational Services Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
A cloud chamber and gold foil in a simple alpha-particle scattering experiment illustrates the historic Rutherford experiment which led to the nuclear model of the atom. Behaviour of alpha particles clarified by use of large scale models illustrating the nuclear atom and Coulomb scattering.

results.title: The Russia house
results.creator_credit: Panthe Entertainment, Paul Maslansky and Fred Schepisi
results.brief_description: When Katya (Michelle Pfeiffer), a beautiful Russian book editor attempts to send British publisher Barley Blair (Sean Connery) a manuscript written by “Dante” (Klaus Maria Brandauer), a noted scientist, she unwittingly involves him in a world of international espionage. The explosive manuscript - which, if published in the West could dramatically alter the global balance of world power - is intercepted by the West’s spy-masters, who then send Blair to Russia to gain more information on the mysterious manuscript. But when Blair, who has a deep affection for Russia and its people finds himself falling in love with the beautiful Katya, he must decide whose side he really is on. This adaptation of a novel by John Le Carre was scripted by playwright Tom Stoppard. It features a score by Jerry Goldsmith with Brandon Marsalis as a soloist. Other cast members include James Fox, Roy Scheider, J. T. Walsh and John Mahoney. (Awards: Golden Globe 1991: best actress for Michelle Pfeiffer)
